metadata.case_name: Custodian of Evacuee Property v. Respondent No. 1

facts.text: Mrs. Zohra Naqvi, wife of a Police official of the then United Provinces (now Uttar Pradesh), was in Teheran in the year 1947 alongwith her husband.
Mrs. Naqvi purchased a property from the Improvement Trust, Lucknow for a sum of Rs. 6,400/-.
Mrs. Naqvi did not come to India at all till 1962 when she sold this property to the sons of respondent No. 1 and one Mrs. Jain.
Husband of Mrs. Naqvi had been posted in Teheran since some time in 1942.
Mrs. Naqvi left the United Provinces even before the 1st March, 1947 and was in Teheran till she left for Pakistan from there.
Mrs. Naqvi migrated to Pakistan from Teheran/Persia after 1st March, 1947 and was resident in Pakistan after the partition of India.
Mrs. Naqvi was unable to occupy, supervise or manage her property in the United Provinces.
Possession of the property had been taken by her son who came to India in 1948 for that purpose specifically whereas Mrs. Naqvi continued to reside in Pakistan.
Mrs. Naqvi was a Pakistani national.
Mrs. Naqvi sent the money from Teheran in 1947.
On 24-6-1949 the United Provinces Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949 came into force.
Before the purchase of this property the 1st respondent had applied to the 1st appellant to be informed whether the property in question is an evacuee property and received a reply in the negative.
On 25-3-1963 the 1st appellant passed an order declaring the property as an evacuee property.
On 7-3-1964 a notification was issued acquiring the disputed plot under section 12 of the Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954.

The 1st respondent filed a revision petition to the Assistant Custodian General who directed that the property should be handed over to the 1st respondent but that the sum of Rs. 42,000/- being the sale price of the property, which had been deposited with the Allahabad Bank, Lucknow could be taken by the Custodian.
The 1st respondent's application to the 1st appellant to issue a sale certificate in his favour having produced no result he filed a writ petition.
The writ petition was dismissed by a learned Judge of the Allahabad High Court but on appeal a Division Bench of the High Court allowed the respondent's appeal.
This appeal has been filed on the basis of a certificate granted by the High Court.
Sum of Rs. 42,000/- paid by the 1st respondent to Mrs. Naqvi and deposited by her in the Allahabad Bank, Lucknow.

legal_issues.text: Whether Mrs. Naqvi was an evacuee under section 2(c)(i) or section 2(c)(ii) of the United Provinces Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949.
Whether the property vested in the Custodian under section 5 of the Ordinance.
Whether the reply to the 1st respondent's enquiry that the property was not evacuee property binds the Custodian or the Government.
Whether the sum of Rs. 42,000/- sale proceeds is evacuee property.

petitioner_arguments.text: Mrs. Naqvi was an evacuee under section 2(c)(ii) of the Ordinance as she was resident in Pakistan after partition and unable to occupy, supervise or manage her property.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 2(c)(ii) of United Provinces Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949

petitioner_arguments.text: Property automatically vested in Custodian under section 5; notification under section 6 not necessary.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 5 and 6 of United Provinces Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949; Section 58 of Central Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950

petitioner_arguments.text: Reply to enquiry does not bind the Custodian; government cannot be estopped by officer's representation from enforcing statutory prohibition.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Howell v. Falmouth Boat Construction Co. Ltd.

respondent_arguments.text: Mrs. Naqvi had not left United Provinces on or after 1st March 1947 but migrated to Pakistan from Teheran; not evacuee under section 2(c)(i).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 2(c)(i) of United Provinces Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949

respondent_arguments.text: Enquiry reply that property not evacuee binds the Custodian.

court_reasoning.text: Mrs. Naqvi left United Provinces before 1st March 1947 so clause (i) does not apply but clearly clause (ii) applies as she was resident in Pakistan after partition and unable to occupy, supervise or manage property.
court_reasoning.key_observation: She was an evacuee under section 2(c)(ii).

court_reasoning.text: Division Bench erred in refusing to consider section 2(c)(ii); issue was raised in writ petition, order of 1st appellant, and revision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Courts must consider all applicable provisions.

court_reasoning.text: Property automatically vested in Custodian under section 5 of Ordinance No. 1 of 1949; repeal by section 58 of 1950 Act continued vesting, no need for section 7 action.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Vesting automatic upon Ordinance coming into force.

court_reasoning.text: Enquiry reply does not bind; follows House of Lords in Howell disapproving Robertson; no estoppel against statute.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Illegality not cured by misleading assumption of authority.

holdings.text: Mrs. Naqvi was an evacuee under section 2(c)(ii) of the Ordinance.
Property was evacuee property and vested in Custodian.
Government department's representation does not estop enforcement of statutory vesting.
Sale proceeds of Rs. 42,000/- deposited in bank are not evacuee property.

precedents_cited.relevance: Reliance on government assurance estoppel; disapproved by House of Lords.

precedents_cited.case_name: Howell v. Falmouth Boat Construction Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: No estoppel against statutory prohibition by government representation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ebrahim Abbobaker and Another v. Tek Chand Dolwani
precedents_cited.relevance: Not helpful to respondents on estoppel.

precedents_cited.case_name: Zafar Ali Shah v. Assistant Custodian of Evacuee Property

statutes_cited.name: United Provinces Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Defined evacuee and evacuee property; automatic vesting in Custodian.

statutes_cited.name: Central Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Repeal of Ordinance continued vesting; section 7 not required if already vested.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; property declared evacuee property vested in Custodian; High Court judgment set aside; sale proceeds Rs. 42,000/- not evacuee property.
outcome.relief_granted: Property vests with Custodian; no sale certificate to respondent.

key_quotes.text: There can be no doubt that she was an evacuee within the meaning of that word under section 2(c)(ii) and the property in question was an evacuee property.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The property automatically vested in the Custodian by virtue of the provision of section 5 of the United Provinces Ordinance No. 1 of 1949.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We are of opinion that the view taken by the House of Lords is the correct one and not the one taken by Lord Denning.
key_quotes.speaker: court
